article:
Linda British was an outstanding teacher who felt that if she had the time, she would like to create great art and poetry. When she was 28, however, she began to get severe   _  . Her doctors discovered that she had an enormous brain tumor  . They told her that her   _  of surviving an operation were about 2 percent. Therefore,  rather than  operate immediately, they chose to wait for six months.
The night before the operation after six months, she   _  to give herself away.
She made a  _  , in which she would donate all of her
body parts to those who needed them in  _  of her
death.
  _  , Linda died after the operation. Afterwards, her eyes went to an eye   _  in
Bethesda, Maryland, and from there to a recipient in South Carolina. A young
man, aged 28, went from darkness to  _  . That young
man was so  _  that he wrote to the eye bank thanking
them for existing.
  _  , he said he wanted to thank the parents of the donator. They must   _  be
magnificent people to have a child who would  give away  her
eyes. He was given the  _  of the British family
on Staten Island. He arrived unannounced and rang the doorbell. After hearing
his introduction, Mrs. British  reached out  and hugged
him. She said, "Young man, if you've got  _  to
go, my husband and I would love you to spend your weekend with us."
He stayed, and   _  he was looking around Linda's room, he saw that she'd read Hegel.
He'd read Hegel in Braille as well.
The next morning Mrs. British was looking at him and said, "You know, I'm sure I've seen you somewhere before." All of a sudden she   _  . She ran upstairs and
pulled out the last picture Linda had drawn. It was a portrait of her ideal
man.
The picture was almost the same as this young man who had received Linda's eyes.
Then her mother read the   _  poem Linda had written on her deathbed. It  _  :
Two hearts passing in the night
Falling in love
Never able to gain each other's sight.
